questions.text:
1. A 42-year-old man noticed a slow, progressive, painless plaque on the side of the neck. He did not complain of any other systemic signs and symptoms. Which of the following tests are useful in this case?

1. HIV 2. Skin biopsy 3. KOH mount 4. Chest X-ray
questions.solution:
Skin biopsy and Chest X-ray are useful in this case.

The above clinical scenario of a slow, progressive, painless plaque on the side of the neck and the characteristic reddish-brown nodules, plaques, and ulcers with variable scarring and a serpiginous edge are suggestive of lupus vulgaris. Lupus vulgaris is a form of cutaneous tuberculosis that occurs in previously sensitised individuals. 

Skin biopsy is usually helpful, but since the quantity of bacilli encountered in cutaneous lesions is small, stains for acid-fast bacilli are usually negative. A chest X-ray will help to analyse the pulmonary involvement.

Lupus vulgaris originates from an underlying focus of tuberculosis, typically in a bone, joint, or lymph node, or maybe from the hematogenous and lymphatic spread. It can also occur over a primary site of inoculation, such as the site of scrofuloderma scar, BCG vaccine, and after a tattoo. 

It presents as a slowly enlarging plaque with an elevated border and central atrophy. The edges of the lesion are often serpiginous in shape and heal with scarring. In India, the buttocks and trunk are more frequently involved. In Europe, most of the lesions are present on the head, neck, and face. The diascopy of lesions reveals diagnostic apple jelly nodules.

Polymerase chain reaction has been successfully used to confirm the diagnosis. Standard multidrug therapy for tuberculosis is used for the treatment. Isoniazid monotherapy is not given anymore due to the emergence of isoniazid-resistant Mycobacterium tuberculosis strains.

2. Which of the following are side effects of topical corticosteroids?

1. Hypertrichosis 2. Acneiform eruption 3. Atrophy 4. Bluish-grey skin discolouration
questions.solution:
Hypertrichosis, Acneiform eruption and Atrophy are side effects of topical corticosteroids.

Side effects of topical corticosteroids

Local side effects Systemic side effects (rare)
  • Cutaneous atrophy
  • Skin fragility
  • Purpura
  • Striae
  • Telangiectasia (vasodilatation)
  • Perioral/periocular dermatitis
  • Acneiform/rosaceiform eruptions
  • Tachyphylaxis
  • Rebound
  • Contact allergy
  • Promotion of infection (herpes simplex, dermatophyte, candida)
  • Cataracts
  • Glaucoma
  • Impaired wound healing
  • Hypertrichosis
  • Pigment alteration
  • Adrenal suppression
  • Cushingoid features
  • Hypertension
  • Hyperglycaemia
  • Low birth weight (with super-potent topical corticosteroids)

 

 

 

 

 

 


Other options:

Bluish-grey skin discolouration is seen in inflammatory diseases and due to some drugs like phenothiazines and minocycline.

questions.text: 3. A 30-year-old man complained of painful lesions on his palms and soles. He also gave a history of sexual contact and a transient genital lesion one month ago. Which of the following tests is most appropriate for him?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of a 30-year-old man complaining of painful lesions on his palms and soles, with a history of sexual contact and a transient genital lesion one month ago, suggests the most probable diagnosis to be secondary syphilis. A serological test is most appropriate for him.

Syphilis is caused by Treponema pallidum, a spirochete bacterium. It is a sexually transmitted infection. A history of sexual contact and a transient genital lesion one month ago suggests a painless indurated chancre, which is usually single. This stage is primary syphilis, and the chancre heals spontaneously in 3–8 weeks.

Secondary syphilis is characterised by generalised manifestations that occur on the skin and mucous membranes. Rashes in secondary syphilis are non-itchy, coppery red in colour and symmetrical in distribution. These first appear at around 8 weeks. Constitutional symptoms include fever, headache and bone and joint pains that are more evident at night.

Serological testing is the most important screening test. It is done using a standard non-treponemal antibody test (VDRL, RPR) and a specific treponemal antibody test(TPHA, FTA-ABS). The VDRL slide test is widely used and requires the microscopic demonstration of antigen–antibody flocculation in heat-inactivated serum.

Reactivity to non-treponemal antibody tests develops 1–4 weeks after the chancre appears in primary syphilis. Specific treponemal antibody tests are qualitative procedures and detect antibodies to antigenic determinants of treponemes. They do not help assess treatment responses.

Treponema pallidum can be identified by dark-field microscopy. It shows corkscrew motility. Molecular amplification tests, like the Polymerase chain reaction, can also be used for identification, especially where interpretation of serological test results is difficult.

Pearl PM2340: Stages of syphilis

Primary syphilis:

* Chancre - Painless, indurated, usually single. The chancre self heals in 1-4 months.

* Lymphadenopathy - Painless, unilateral or bilateral, shotty and rubbery inguinal nodes

* Dory flop sign - As the chancre is too hard to fold, it will flip over once the prepuce is retracted back.

Secondary syphilis:



* A & B: Generalized non-itchy rash with no vesicles present on the palm and sole. This is the most common lesion.

* C & D: Condyloma lata.

* E: Moth-eaten non-scarring alopecia

* F: Mucous patches are flat erosions on the tongue that can coalesce to form snail track ulcers. These are the most infectious lesions.

* G: Pigmentary plaques

* H: Psoriasiform syphilitic lesions

* Generalized diffuse non-tender lymphadenopathy

Tertiary syphilis:

* Gummatous syphilis are deep punched-out ulcers, with gum-like secretions on the floor

* Pseudo-chancre redux is a gumma occurring at the site of a previously healed ulcer  

* CVS - Aortitis and aneurysm of the ascending aorta

* CNS - General paresis of the insane and tabes dorsalis 

Latent syphilis is the period between secondary and tertiary syphilis. In this period the patient is asymptomatic clinically and only serological evidence of the infection is present. It is classified into:

* Early latent syphilis - Within 1 year of infection

* Late latent syphilis - After 1 year of infection

Pearl PM0026: Syphilis - Diagnostic Serology

Nontreponemal tests (VDRL, RPR)

VDRL- Venereal disease Research Laboratory test

RPR- Rapid Plasma Reagin test

* Quantitative tests(titres)

* Reagin antibody tests; based on cardiolipin antigen

* VDRL can be used to test CSF whereas RPR cannot be used

* RPR does not require preheating of serum unlike VDRL

* VDRL requires light microscope for interpretation whereas RPR can be read macroscopically

* Decrease in titers confirms treatment

* Sensitivity of RPR(86%)>VDRL(76%) in primary syphilis

Treponemal Tests

FTA-ABS- Fluorescent Treponemal Antibody Absorption test

TPI-Treponema pallidum immobilization test

TPPA-Treponema pallidum particle agglutination assay

TPHA-Treponema pallidum haemagglutination test

EIA-Enzyme-linked ImmunoAssay

* Detect antibody to treponemal antigens

* Qualitative tests

* Greater sensitivity in early infection

* Positive even after treatment hence cannot be used to detect reinfection.

* First test to be positive: FTA-ABS

* Most specific: TPHA,TPPA, EIA

questions.text:
4. Which of the following statements are correct?

1. The epidermis is derived from the ectoderm. 2. The hypodermis and dermis are derived from the endoderm. 3. Stratum corneum is the outermost cellular layer. 4. The epidermis regenerates from deeper follicular cells, such as hair follicles and sebaceous glands.
questions.solution:
Statements 1 and 4 are the correct statements. 

The epidermis is derived from the surface ectoderm. During the 2nd month, it presents as two layers- a superficial layer of flat cells called periderm/epitrichium and a deep layer of cuboidal cells called basal/ germinative layer. The cells of the basal layer proliferate to form a third intermediate layer later.

The epidermis regenerates from deeper follicular cells, such as hair follicles and sebaceous glands. This helps to maintain skin homeostasis.

Other statements:

Statement 2: The dermis and hypodermis are derived from mesoderm. The dermatomes give rise only to the dermis on the dorsal aspect of the head and trunk. The dermis of the limbs and that on the lateral and ventral aspects of the trunk arises from lateral plate mesoderm. The dermis over most of the head and the anterior aspect of the neck is derived from the neural crest.

Statement 3: Stratum corneum is not the outermost cellular layer. It is the outermost layer of epidermis, where cells, known as corneocytes, have lost their nuclei and cytoplasmic organelles.

Pearl PM1880: Cells of the epidermis

Cells of the epidermis Origin and location Characteristic features
Keratino-cytes

Present in- All Layers of Epidermis (90-95% of all epidermal cells)

Derived from-Ectoderm

Differentiated in situ

 Rich in the intermediate filaments called keratin that provides mechanical strength to the cell. The keratinocytes in basal layer divide and generate the upper layers. 
Melano-cytes

Present in- Stratum basale

Derived from-Neural Crest

Migrate to the epidermis

 Synthesize melanin in granules called melanosomes that is transferred to keratinocytes of epidermis through elongated processes called dendrites. Each melanocyte transfers melanosomes to 36 keratinocytes. This is called as Epidermal melanin unit (36K:1M)   

Merkel   cells

Present in-Stratum basale (RETE RIDGES)

Derived from-Ectoderm/ Neural Crest

Differentiates in-situ

 Also known as Touch cells or Haascheiban cells. They are Type 1 slow adapting touch receptors.  
Langerhans cells

Present in-Stratum spinosum

Derived from- Bone Marrow

Migrate to Epidermis

 They are dendritic Antigen Presenting Cells (APCs).   Characterized by presence of rod shaped or Tennis Racket shaped granules called Birbeck granules which are seen on electron microscopy.   Immunohistochemical Markers are CD1a, CD207(Langerin) and S100.

questions.text:
5. Which of the following are used to treat scabies in infants?

1. Permethrin 5% 2. Ivermectin 3. Crotamiton 10% 4. Benzyl benzoate 25%
questions.solution:
Permethrin 5% and Crotamiton 10% are used to treat scabies in infants.

Permethrin cream (5%) is the treatment of choice for scabies. It is applied topically twice, 1 week apart, and it is approved for infants ≥ 2 months of age.

Crotamiton (10%) ointment is applied topically overnight on days 1, 2, 3, and 8.

Other options:

Ivermectin is contraindicated in children <15 kg.

Benzyl benzoate (25%) ointment is contraindicated in children.

questions.text: 6. A young man presented with painful vesicular lesions over the genitalia, with superficial erosions. Image as depicted. What is the drug of choice?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of a young man complaining of painful genital vesicular lesions with superficial erosions, with histopathology showing multinucleated giant cells, suggests the most probable diagnosis to be Herpes genitalis (HSV-2), and the drug to be given is Acyclovir.

Acyclovir is the most frequently used for the treatment of HSV infections and is available in IV, oral, and topical formulations. Other drugs that can be used are ganciclovir, famciclovir, and valacyclovir. All these drugs are found to be effective in shortening the duration of symptoms and lesions of mucocutaneous HSV infections in both immunocompromised and immunocompetent patients

Herpes infection can be caused by the HSV-1 and HSV-2 viruses. HSV-1 causes orofacial lesions, i.e. herpes labialis, while HSV-2 mainly causes genital herpes which is characterised by vesiculoulcerative lesions of the penis of the male or the cervix, vulva, vagina, and perineum of the female. Genital herpes is often accompanied by symptoms like fever, headache, malaise, and myalgia, pain, itching, dysuria, vaginal and urethral discharge, and tender inguinal lymphadenopathy.

Diagnosis of herpes simplex virus:

* Most sensitive test- HSV DNA- PCR (can differentiate between HSV 1 and 2)

* Virus isolation 

* Histopathology showing multinucleated giant cells

* Microscopy - Tzanck smear, which is a rapid, diagnostic method, shows Tzanck cells. These are multinucleated giant cells with faceted nuclei and homogenously stained ground-glass chromatin.
